resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

fields.summary: [Python] Default PYARROW_CMAKE_GENERATOR can yield broken libraries with MSVC if the C++ toolchain is different

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.
status.name: Open

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

pitrou commented on issue #6350: ARROW-6757: [Release] Use same CMake generator for C++ and Python when verifying RC, remove Python 3.5 from wheel verification
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6350#issuecomment-581853532
 
 
   Could you open a JIRA to remove the hardcoded CMake generator in `setup.py`?
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the

wesm commented on pull request #6350: ARROW-6757: [Release] Use same CMake generator for C++ and Python when verifying RC, remove Python 3.5 from wheel verification
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6350#discussion_r374846890
 
 

 ##########
 File path: dev/release/verify-release-candidate.bat
 ##########
 @@ -71,7 +71,10 @@ pushd %ARROW_SOURCE%\cpp\build
 @rem This is the path for Visual Studio Community 2017
 call "C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2017\Community\Common7\Tools\VsDevCmd.bat" -arch=amd64
 
-cmake -G "Ninja" ^
 
 Review comment:
   We had this conversation in the past, I think. The MSVC "environment setup" scripts provided by VS are more crude than what can be obtained using the `-G` flag. 
   
   Using an explicit generator it's possible to choose the exact toolchain you want, but you must use msbuild, not Ninja. It would be interesting to know if there's a way to both use Ninja and select the target toolchain. The answer may be no but anyway it would be nice to know
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.

users@infra.apache.org

   +1. I'll open a JIRA (though I'm not sure how we will get setup.py to choose the right generator if one is not passed)

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description:
I encountered this when trying to verify the release with MSVC 2017. It may be particular to this machine or build (though it's 100% reproducible for me). I will check the Windows wheels to see if it occurs there, too

{code}
(C:\tmp\arrow-verify-release\conda-env) λ python
Python 3.7.3 | packaged by conda-forge | (default, Jul  1 2019, 22:01:29) [MSC v.1900 64 bit (AMD64)] :: Anaconda, Inc. on win32
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import pyarrow.csv as pc
>>> pc.ParseOptions()
{code}
fields.summary: [Python] Creating csv.ParseOptions() causes "Windows fatal exception: access violation" with Visual Studio 2017

comments.body: Does the debugger tell you something?
I haven't had a chance to investigate further yet. Will report back once I learn something
I was having other problems with my Miniconda -- I installed a new Miniconda, re-bootstrapped the dev environment, and then was not able to reproduce
This happened again while trying to verify 0.16.0 RC2. I wish I knew what was wrong

I've been able to reproduce this with a fresh Miniconda using the release verification script:

{code}
C:\tmp\arrow-verify-release\conda-env\Library\bin\cmake.exe -DPYTHON_EXECUTABLE=C:\tmp\arrow-verify-release\conda-env\python.exe  -G "Visual Studio 14 2015 Win64" -DPYARROW_BUILD_CUDA=off -DPYARROW_BUILD_FLIGHT=on -DPYARROW_BUILD_GANDIVA=off -DPYARROW_BUILD_DATASET=off -DPYARROW_BUILD_ORC=off -DPYARROW_BUILD_PARQUET=on -DPYARROW_BUILD_PLASMA=off -DPYARROW_BUILD_S3=off -DPYARROW_BUILD_HDFS=off -DPYARROW_USE_TENSORFLOW=off -DPYARROW_BUNDLE_ARROW_CPP=on -DPYARROW_BUNDLE_BOOST=off -DPYARROW_GENERATE_COVERAGE=off -DPYARROW_BOOST_USE_SHARED=on -DPYARROW_PARQUET_USE_SHARED=on -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=release C:\tmp\arrow-verify-release\apache-arrow-0.16.0\python
-- Selecting Windows SDK version 10.0.14393.0 to target Windows 10.0.17763.
-- The C compiler identification is MSVC 19.0.24234.1
-- The CXX compiler identification is MSVC 19.0.24234.1
{code}

It looks like it could be a conflict between the MSVC (VS 2017) used to build libarrow and the configuration {{"Visual Studio 14 2015 Win64"}} being passed by the pyarrow build. 

I'm guessing we should not be hardcoding this in setup.py

https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/python/setup.py#L130

I'll see if setting the environment variable {{PYARROW_CMAKE_GENERATOR}} fixes the problem
Ha, that could very well be the explanation. In any case, it looks wrong for it to be hard-coded like this.
